Mr. Smith, the mild-mannered chairman and chief executive of Hughes Electronics, hardly stands out among the Armani-clad bankers and other Upper East Side prima donnas. But for 14 years, Mr. Smith, now 56, has had a substantial role in transforming Hughes, once an anchor of Southern California's military industry, into a technology powerhouse and the third-largest provider of pay television in the United States, behind AT&T and Time Warner. Its best-known venture, DirecTV, already has more than nine million subscribers who receive programming in their homes using pizza-sized satellite dishes.

Later, on the strength of a contract from I.B.M. to development MS-DOS, a simple personal computer operating system, Microsoft grew into the world's dominant independent software publisher. Mr. Allen, through his Vulcan Ventures, is a powerful force in new media and other technology companies. docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re one letter that commented on the column about WordPerfect: The letter writer was correct, strictly speaking, in pointing out that the format of documents created in Adobe Acrobat is PDF, not Adobe Acrobat, because the latter is an application. The letter writer does split hairs, though: He should also have noted that Microsoft Word and Corel WordPerfect are both applications, not formats; they are each capable of saving files in many different formats. Similarly, HTML is a language, not a format. We often use shorthand to describe the formats of the documents created in certain applications or languages. Many graphics professionals refer to the Acrobat format, rather than the PDF format. I think that usage is the key, not strict interpretation. PAUL UKENA New York

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR years, stock options granted by the nation's fastest-growing companies have been capitalism's version of a free lunch. Now, with new-economy stocks tumbling, the bill for the meal may be coming due. In recent years, shares of Dell Computer, Cisco Systems, Microsoft and others zoomed ahead of old-line companies' stocks on the strength of outsized earnings growth. An increasingly large component of that growth came from stock options that are used to pay employees but are not considered an expense. Options, which cost stockholders in share dilution, cost companies nothing to issue and actually save them money on payroll costs. Those savings go to the bottom line, making earnings growth at many companies look artificially high.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hold your horsemen! Last week the market guru James J. Cramer, once famed for his boundless optimism about tech stocks, declared himself, yes, disillusioned with the sector. He detailed his disappointment with the ''four horsemen'' of tech: Dell, Microsoft, Intel and Cisco. But in the same week an article in Business Week Online also spoke of the ''four horsemen of the new economy'' -- Cisco again, but the others were Oracle, EMC and Sun. Aside from the fact that most people probably have no idea what these companies do (I'm a bit blurry myself), the interesting thing is that while Mr. Cramer's list is dominated by companies associated with PC's, the other list is all about computer networks. And that suggests an interpretation not only of Mr. Cramer's loss of faith but of the broader disillusionment of investors, a disillusionment that has pushed the Nasdaq down more than 20 percent from its summer highs. Think of it as the revenge of Joseph Schumpeter.

docs.lead_paragraph: 1. The sight of a large piece of furniture being hoisted through the window of a New York City apartment is no big deal. The sight of an oil tank being airlifted by crane into a loft, however, might raise a few eyebrows. This was definitely the case when the 7,200-gallon tank from an oil truck arrived at Josh Morton's building just over a year ago (a, b). Can't live without a tank of your own? Morton acquired the rehabilitated tank for a mere $3,500 from Garafano Tank Service in Paterson, N.J. That's about $50,000 less than the cost of a new truck. And there's no need to worry about fumes or trace petroleum: each three-ton tank is meticulously steam-cleaned by Peter Garafano and his crew. 2. If you think a tank is hard to move, imagine what it would be like to transport LOT/EK's next project: the fuselage of a 747 jumbo jet, which the firm intends to turn into a new student lounge for the University of Washington. It's understandable why the architects made the connection between the university and airplane parts: the Boeing Company was the cornerstone of Seattle's pre-Microsoft economy. Boeing worked with university engineers in the mid-1930's to create the Kirsten Wind Tunnel, shown here. The tunnel, part of the University of Washington Aeronautical Laboratory, simulates high-speed winds and played a crucial role in the development of commercial aircraft.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR more than a year, ''Play,'' a genre-straddling collection of electronic dance songs by the techno auteur known as Moby, has been an oddity among the usual suspects -- teen idols, slick VH-1 stalwarts, rappers, R-and-B divos and divas, truculent frat rockers, Shania Twain -- hovering in the top half of the Billboard 200 album chart. The record is a big hit. It has sold one million copies in the United States, and has been on the Billboard charts for 59 straight weeks; overseas, where techno is more entrenched in the pop mainstream, ''Play'' has sold an additional three million copies. In an age of blockbuster albums, those numbers are not earth-shattering, but ''Play'' has achieved a kind of ubiquity that has eluded even superstars like 'N Sync and Celine Dion. Moby has licensed all 18 of the album's tracks for commercial use. ''Honey,'' an urgent, up-tempo dance tune driven by a sample from a decades-old blues recording, was used in two different soap operas; the lush synthesizer strains of ''Porcelain'' tinkled on the soundtrack of the Leonardo DiCaprio movie ''The Beach'' and in television commercials for a car, a washing machine and Microsoft. This mass-market saturation has made ''Play'' one of the most-heard of all recent records; people to whom the name Moby means nothing may find themselves humming along to the album's familiar tunes.

docs.lead_paragraph: I ADORE the Met, there's no question about that,'' Alberto W. Vilar said. ''I go into that place, and I get goose pimples. Wow, this is the Met! My rich friends laugh at me, because I sit in the same seat every night, in the first row. A101, that's my seat. I want to watch the conductor, the pit, the stage. Not only that, I hold court. My friends come up. They know where I am.'' If anyone has earned -- or at least, purchased -- the right to hold court at the Met, it is Mr. Vilar, a 60-year-old Cuban-American investor and opera fan who has lately been parlaying his acuity in the world of high-tech stocks into a philanthropic boon for the opera world. A member of the board of the Metropolitan Opera since 1995, he contributed $25 million to the company's endowment fund, and he has pledged to underwrite 10 Met productions, at about $2 million apiece. So far, he has paid for the company's productions of ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' ''La Cenerentola,'' ''La Traviata'' and ''Le Nozze di Figaro.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Like a lot of start-ups, Cardima Inc., a maker of medical devices in Fremont, Calif., found it hard to predict how big a permanent staff it would need. So, in 1993, the company hired mostly independent contractors to fill the gap. Independent contractors work for a specified length of time for specified pay, and the move made good business sense. But it also created a management problem. Because companies do not withhold taxes or make Social Security payments on the earnings of such workers, any decision to rely on large numbers of them usually sounds an alarm bell at the Internal Revenue Service and state employment agencies. And that is exactly what happened.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE average Web surfer opens the Netscape or Internet Explorer browser, punches in a Web address, comes to a Web page, then clicks from page to page. When lost, the person tries to maneuver through an array of bookmarks or, more often than not, resorts to the Back button. In 1994, that page-turning process seemed revolutionary. Today, it not only sounds run-of-the-mill but is also considered by many new Internet companies to be, well, ridiculous. Why should a person who wants a few headlines have to open a full page of information? Why should anyone have to click on link after link to get to the right information? And how many people really go back to all those Web sites they bookmark?

docs.lead_paragraph: Goodyear, Texaco, Colgate-Palmolive, MCI WorldCom and eight other large corporations earned more than $12.2 billion in profits in 1996 through 1998, but none of them ended up owing corporate income taxes over that period, according to a study released yesterday. Indeed, as a group, the companies received $535 million in credits or refunds, the report found. The study of 250 large publicly traded companies showed that 24 owed no tax or received credits against past or future tax obligations in 1998, up from 13 in 1997 and 16 in 1996. The study also found that 71 of the 250 companies paid taxes at less than half the official 35 percent corporate rate during the three-year period.

Prices soon rallied, but the Dow Jones industrial average still closed under 10,000 for the first time since March. docs.lead_paragraph: Last week George W. Bush accused Al Gore of ''analog thinking in a digital age.'' It's a terrific line; my compliments to whoever wrote it. It's also a bit unfair. True, Mr. Gore didn't invent the Internet -- but then, he never said he had. What he did say was, ''During my service in the United States Congress, I took the initiative in creating the Internet.'' That was a deeply unfortunate sentence -- but what makes it so unfortunate is that now it is impossible for Mr. Gore to get the credit he actually deserves. Declan McCullagh, the Wired writer who first played up Mr. Gore's remark, puts it this way: the vice president ''was one of the first politicians to realize that those bearded, bespectacled researchers were busy crafting something that could, just maybe, become pretty important.''

But in these boom times, even a relatively modest increase in the nation's gross domestic product at a annual rate of 2.7 percent, is still healthy growth, and the numbers suggest that the dip might only be temporary. Government outlays dropped, particularly as census takers left the payroll, and retailers sold stockpiled merchandise. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Sony's PlayStation 2 video game console made its long-awaited and predictably frenzied North American debut yesterday. But what should have been a banner day for Sony was clouded by reminders of the difficulties it has had in bringing the device to market. A month ago, Sony warned that it would have just 500,000 units in stores for the debut instead of the million originally projected. And in releasing its quarterly earnings yesterday, the company was clearly feeling the financial pain of fumbling the rollout. The expense of racing to recover from production problems contributed to a 57 percent decline in net profits in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with a year earlier.

''Some accounts were being created that did not match our normal audit logs,'' Mr. Schmidt, the corporate security officer for the Microsoft Corporation, said yesterday. New accounts that were not created by the usual procedures raised a red flag: a computer intruder could be working his way into the software giant's network.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE SENATE THE MICROSOFT VOTE -- With polls suggesting a down-to-the-wire race and his opponent buoyed by endorsements from Seattle's two big newspapers, Senator Slade Gorton is getting help from a prominent friend, Bill Gates. Mr. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, showed up the other night at a fund-raiser in Kirkland, Wash., telling the crowd, which included several dozen Gates employees: ''We're all very lucky to have him as a senator. And I think I can speak for everybody here in saying we wish you success on Nov. 7.'' Mr. Gorton, a three-term Republican and a critic of the government's antitrust case against the software giant, is the only candidate to whom Mr. Gates has personally made a campaign donation this year, according to Federal Election Commission records. All told, Microsoft employees and the company's political action committee have given about $113,000 to Mr. Gorton in this election cycle, and about $12,500 to his opponent, former Representative Maria Cantwell, a Democrat. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE A. BOSSIDY had sworn that he would raise annual revenue at AlliedSignal to $20 billion by the time he retired as chairman and chief executive last April. His determination had even become a company slogan: ''20 in 20,'' his people would say, lopping off zeros. But as his retirement approached, revenue was still $5 billion short of the goal. So last year, Mr. Bossidy acquired Honeywell Inc., creating a company with Honeywell's name and $24 billion in revenue. There was another reason for the acquisition. Both companies were big in the manufacture of aircraft components like jet engines, cockpit controls and navigational devices. Combining their product lines promised more market power. But adding to the top line, and the profit that such additional revenue can bring, can be slow going in these competitive times, and mergers are a handy shortcut.

docs.lead_paragraph: HISTORY has not been kind to the computer mouse. It emerged from military research to help with ''augmenting human intellect,'' as its developer, Douglas Engelbart, put it in his financial application. Thirty-two years ago next month, the first public demonstration of a mouse was enough to attract an attentive crowd at a computer technology conference. Today, at best, most computer users give their mouse as much thought as, say, the handle of their refrigerator. At worst, for some people, jabbing and jiggling a mouse all day can contribute to various hand-numbing repetitive stress injuries.

The new browser has a My Sidebar section on the left side of the page, which organizes and stores buddy lists and links to favorite news, sports and weather sites. Gone are the days when most programs for personal computers would run on anything from a 486 chip on up. This year, many new titles require a PC with a Pentium chip, usually starting at 133 megahertz or higher. Most Macintosh software requires a PowerPC chip or better.

Laptops have become thinner and lighter, yet more powerful, and hand-held computers can do more and do it more easily through color screens, increased memory and greater expansibility. Browsing the Web and sending e-mail with a cell phone has become commonplace. Hand-held computers in particular, like the Handspring Visor and the new Pocket PC devices running Microsoft's updated mini-operating system, have made great leaps from their humble origins as simple electronic Rolodexes. The new hand-helds have become traveling compact versions of a full-blown desktop system, with add-on features -- like modems, cameras and MP3 players -- that allow even more versatility.

docs.lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY: As a New York City police officer, I was reminded recently of a morning in the early 1990's when I was on duty at a demonstration of civil disobedience at Tompkins Square Park. Ten fellow officers from Brooklyn and I were assigned to an outside corner of the park and were told we could expect a 12- to 14-hour day. Things had quieted down, and we were prepared for a long, uneventful time standing in one spot. As is typical, we were also concerned with finding bathrooms and with keeping sore feet to a minimum. We chatted with neighborhood residents and posed for photographs. About noon, a man in his late 20's with a blue Mohawk haircut took up a position across from our post. He was wearing a black T-shirt with a stylized, red circled ''A'' on the front, which, so far as I knew, was a symbol of the anarchists. He carried a petition on a clipboard, produced a bullhorn and for several hours tried to gather a crowd and signatures, pleading in vain with passers-by to ''take back our park'' and speaking for workers' solidarity and against multinational capitalism and exploitation. Eventually he realized we were regarding him as a source of entertainment rather than a threat, and he became vitriolic about the officers present. By dusk he had left in disgust.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was during a recent job search that Donald Bell gave in to the temptation to bug his own e-mail. Mr. Bell, 55, had e-mailed dozens of resumes to prospective employers and received scant response. Naturally he wondered: was he being rejected, or had his messages gone unread? Anyone who has been left hanging knows it is the sort of nagging question that is rarely answered. But thanks to a furtive application of a feature common to the latest e-mail programs, Mr. Bell was able to learn, undetected, that the intended recipients were indeed opening his messages. docs.lead_paragraph: There is something not entirely rational about the book industry's current love affair with electronic books. Few people have ever read a whole book on a screen. No one knows how many people will ever want to. And book publishers have been burned before: A decade ago, book publishers produced thousands of electronic books on computer discs with game-like interactive features, pictures and sounds, but consumers were not interested. Nevertheless, major book publishers, technology companies, online booksellers and new electronic book middlemen are betting hundreds of millions of dollars this year on the future market for digital books. In the latest twist, the media and technology company Gemstar-TV Guide International is in talks with the nation's largest bookstore chain, Barnes & Noble, about a range of ventures that may include a merger or acquisition, a deal that would make sense only if electronic books became a truly significant business.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE popularity contest between Internet Explorer and Netscape Navigator is one of the most intriguing spectacles of the digital age. Each year, these two Web browsers appear in new versions, flush with features that Microsoft and Netscape have unapologetically stolen from each other. In no other industry do the two market leaders invest so much money and effort in their products and then distribute them free. After two years of programming efforts and six months of availability in free preview form, Netscape and its parent, America Online, released Netscape 6 last week in Windows, Macintosh and Linux versions. Unveiling a new version of Netscape Navigator now may, at first glance, seem to be a pathetic gesture. At this point, Netscape is like a mouse lobbing spitballs at an oncoming steamroller. According to the analyst group WebSideStory, 86 percent of the world's Web surfers use Internet Explorer. (Whether Internet Explorer's supremacy results from its being built into Windows, as Netscape says, or because it's simply better, as Microsoft claims, is another question entirely.)

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost every Fortune 500 company these days has a ''competitive intelligence'' (or C.I.) unit or farms out its spy activities. Coca-Cola, 3M, Dow Chemical, General Electric and Intel all maintain a staff dedicated to uncovering what business rivals are up to. Motorola hired away a star from the Central Intelligence Agency to create its corporate intelligence division. Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, boasts a 25-member competitive intelligence arm. Although the word ''espionage'' conjures images of shady characters in overcoats who are hired to steal nuclear secrets, today's corporate spies are decidedly less glamorous. For one, they are hired to find out prosaic things like a company's marketing plan, the state of its R. and D. or a factory's production capacity. (Valuable, yes, but not sexy.) And instead of fancy gizmos like exploding pens and secret decoder rings, often all they need to get the job done is a telephone.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of these days -- perhaps this year, perhaps next -- John M. Deutch is going to get a call from his lawyer. If he is lucky, he will learn that his ''case'' has been resolved. Of course, it may not be a ''case'' in the formal sense; he has not been charged with any criminal offense nor has he been informed by the Justice Department that he is the target of a criminal investigation. But ''case'' is probably still the best word to describe the slowly unwinding chain of events that began with the discovery in late 1996 that Deutch -- then the outgoing director of central intelligence, as the C.I.A.'s chief is formally known -- had placed classified files on an unclassified Apple computer provided to him by the agency for his use at home. Security is taken very seriously at the C.I.A. The first person new recruits meet is a security officer, and the first course they take is C.I.A. 101, a how-to brief on protecting information. Everybody who works in the agency's headquarters in Langley, Va., has a security clearance, including the cleaning staff. ''Security regulations apply to everybody,'' said one senior intelligence official who used to be second in command for security at the agency's directorate of administration. ''It doesn't matter who they are or where they are.''

docs.lead_paragraph: As part of an initiative to help end the so-called digital divide, Microsoft Corporation will give $88 million in software and $12.3 million in cash to the Boys and Girls Clubs of America over the next five years, William H. Gates, the company's chairman, and a phalanx of politicians announced in Harlem yesterday. The initiative, Club Tech, an expansion of a pilot begun in 1999, will establish or augment computer facilities and instruction at the more than 2,600 clubs worldwide. The computers and Internet connections are supplied by PowerUP, a nonprofit organization founded last year that works with companies like America Online, Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard. Speaking to more than 100 children at the Dunlevy Milbank Boys and Girls Club yesterday, Mr. Gates said the gift would help the clubs expand on ''neat new things.'' He added, ''In fact, I'm envious that you have something far better than what I had as a kid,'' He was speaking of the club's technology room, which he toured earlier in the day. G.M. said that it would produce 14.5 percent fewer vehicles in the next three months than it did in the first quarter of this year. Its shares fell 69 cents, to $51.38. docs.lead_paragraph: THE week before we were married, my fiancee and I had what sounded like a great idea: After scanning photos from every phase of our lives, we would use the computer to create a slide show. We'd play it on a TV at the wedding reception so our guests would have something to watch as they munched carrot sticks and waited for the real party to begin. On paper, the idea was a dream; in practice, it became a nightmare of flaky slide-show software, expensive computer-to-TV adapters and all-nighters. We couldn't have guessed that only five years later, Iomega would introduce the FotoShow: a sleek, compact, $300 disk drive that turns the digital photos on any Zip disk into a TV slide show. If we had known, we might have postponed the wedding.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: WOMAN MINIMIZES ROLE IN DEATH -- A woman who was convicted with a friend in the 1997 slaying of a man in Central Park testified in a deposition this week that she had played only a minimal part in the crime. The woman, Daphne Abdela, and her friend Christopher Vasquez, both now 18, are being tried in a $150 million wrongful-death suit for the killing of Michael McMorrow, a 44-year-old real estate broker, in May 1997. Mr. McMorrow was repeatedly stabbed, then disemboweled, and his body left in a park lake. Ms. Abdela, who pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter, for which she is serving a 10-year maximum sentence, testified for the first time under oath Tuesday that it was Mr. Vasquez alone who stabbed Mr. McMorrow, according to her lawyer, Paul Callan. Arnold N. Kriss, the lawyer for Mr. Vasquez, would not comment. Lawyers for the McMorrow family said both defendants were responsible. Eun Lee Koh (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: NORMALLY, Web browsers quietly mind their own business, speeding through Web pages at their masters' whim. Now a study from Princeton University has found that one part of Web browsers -- the caches -- might also allow nosey or unscrupulous Web site operators to spy on their visitors' browsing habits. Edward W. Felten, co-director of Princeton's Secure Internet Programming Laboratory and co-author of the paper with Michael Schneider, said he was not aware of any actual snooping using a technique he has discovered. Nevertheless, he said that this potential intrusion poses a significant threat to privacy. The study concludes that there is no practical way to prevent it. ''It's part of the whole picture of Web privacy,'' Dr. Felten said. ''It could be used by an employer who wanted to see if employees were visiting Web sites about specific medical conditions or political organizations.''

docs.lead_paragraph: THE relentless fall of the euro in 2000 at least until recently -- has lulled Americans into thinking the European Union has lost some credibility as an economic power. Add to this the failure of the recent summit meeting of European leaders in Nice to reach agreement on sharing power, and it is easy to cast aside the ambitions of Europe to form a less fractious and much bigger union. Even the news media in France, which played host to the meeting, were critical of the event. But European finance ministers like Karl-Heinz Grasser of Austria; Vincenzo Visco, head of Italy's Treasury; and Laurent Fabius, the French finance minister, exhibit little loss of confidence. To the contrary, they point out, Europe is growing at an annual rate of 4 percent and unemployment is at last falling. Not bad for a set of countries roundly criticized for so-called inflexible labor policies and squashing their entrepreneurial instincts. ''Remember that 10 years ago no one believed we could form a single market, either,'' Mr. Grasser said.

docs.lead_paragraph: If Al Gore wants to appreciate the forces that defeated him in Florida over the last six weeks, he need not look much beyond the scene on Monday morning in the Senate chamber in Tallahassee: Gov. Jeb Bush and the state's entire Republican leadership presiding in triumph as Florida's 25 electoral votes were finally delivered to George W. Bush. The ceremony was more than a celebration of Mr. Bush's ascent to the White House. It was a display of the depth and complexity of the political forces Mr. Gore confronted here in Florida. And it demonstrated the extent to which Mr. Gore was up against far more than the presidential nominee of the Republican Party. Mr. Gore may have had some reason to feel that he was fighting the government of Florida itself.

docs.lead_paragraph: Aside from his impeachment, nothing defined Bill Clinton's years in the White House more than prosperity. Advances in technology reinvigorated some industries and created others.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was not so long ago that Sega dominated the video game market. Its Genesis game system, released in 1989, broke ground with its dazzling graphics and mind-boggling speed, beating competitors' best efforts by leaps and bounds. But today the game for Sega, at least as a maker of hardware, may be over. Amid faltering sales for the company's Dreamcast game console and reports that it is a takeover target, Sega's value, and its future, seem more clearly than ever to be in its software development business.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some art forms are more molecular than others. In fact some are so diffuse and pervasive that we barely see them even when looking right at them. In a literate society, perhaps no form occupies this zone of invisible visibility more completely than typography, which makes type designers among the most influential, if anonymous, artists in history. Hermann Zapf, 82, who is German, is such an artist. A revered figure in the world of type design, book design and publishing, and the related sphere of calligraphy, he is largely unknown to a wider public. Still, millions of people encounter his work daily. He designed two of the core fonts shipped with every Macintosh computer and with all Microsoft Windows software. His best-known typeface, the elegant, subtly modulated sans-serif Optima, is ubiquitous in publishing and advertising. Perhaps most prominently, it was also used for the names carved into the black granite surface of the Vietnam War Memorial in Washington.
